title: 103_s293
content: The Native American Veterans' Memorial Establishment Act may be cited as the Short Title. This Act includes findings related to the establishment of the memorial. The Congress finds that Native Americans have a long tradition of service in the armed forces of the United States, historically serving in numbers exceeding their representation in the population. They have also made sacrifices for their nation and the cause of peace, with the National Museum of the American Indian established as a living memorial to Native Americans. The National Museum of the American Indian serves as a living memorial to Native Americans and is an ideal location to establish a National Native American Veterans' Memorial. This memorial would further the purposes of the museum by allowing all Americans to learn about the proud and courageous tradition of Native American service in the armed forces of the United States. Authorization for establishment of memorial. The Board of Trustees of the National Museum of the American Indian is authorized to design, construct, and maintain a National Native American Veterans' Memorial. The Board shall select a suitable site for the Memorial within the facility provided for by the National Museum of the American Indian Act. They are also authorized to hold a competition to select the design of the Memorial. The Board of Trustees may accept donations to fund the design, construction, and maintenance of the National Native American Veterans' Memorial. The United States Government will not cover any expenses for establishing the Memorial, except for providing the site mentioned in the previous section. The Native American Veterans' Memorial Establishment Act of 1993 defines Native American, Indian, Native Hawaiian, and Alaska Native. It also establishes the short title of the Act and findings related to the establishment of the memorial. The Congress acknowledges the long tradition of Native Americans serving in the Armed Forces, with many receiving honors for their valor. The National Museum of the American Indian serves as a memorial to their contributions to society. The National Museum of the American Indian acknowledges the tradition of Native Americans serving in the Armed Forces and proposes establishing a National Native American Veterans' Memorial to honor their courageous service. The Act defines key terms such as "Native American," "Native Hawaiian," and "Alaska Native." It also establishes the Native American Veterans' Memorial and references the National Museum of the American Indian. The Museum is authorized to design, construct, and maintain a National Native American Veterans' Memorial within its facility in consultation with Native American groups. A competition will be held to select the design, and donations are accepted for the Memorial's expenses. The United States Government will not pay for the expenses of establishing the Memorial, except for providing the site.
